case_vignette:
A 14-year-old male presenting to dermatology clinic with rosy cheeks and a history of easy sunburns and frequent respiratory infections. Physical examination demonstrates a prominent nose and ears, telangiectatic erythema in a malar distribution, and faint hypopigmentation on the cheeks.  Genetic testing is performed and reveals a BLM/RECQL3 mutation.  The patient is diagnosed with Bloom syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by short stature, a prominent nose and ears, and an increased risk of cancer.  The patient is advised to avoid excessive sun exposure and to take regular breaks in shaded areas when outdoors.  The patient is also advised to receive regular vaccinations to prevent respiratory infections.

Physical examination demonstrates a prominent nose and ears, telangiectatic erythema in a malar distribution, and faint hypopigmentation on the cheeks.  Genetic testing is performed and reveals a BLM/RECQL3 mutation.  The patient is diagnosed with Bloom syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by short stature, a prominent nose and ears, and an increased risk of cancer. question: What is the final diagnosis?

Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

I have rosy cheeks, I burn easily in the sun, and I often get respiratory infections.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?

Sun exposure seems to worsen the redness on my face.
Final Diagnosis: Rosacea
